channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [BOOKKEEPER-562] Ability to tell if a ledger is closed or not
item.description:
We need to be able to differentiate between open and closed ledgers, because we want to persist ledgers which are closed and wait for ledgers that are open to close.

There doesn't seem to be an easy way to get a list of closed / open ledgers or to query bk to ask if a specific ledger is open or closed.
item.summary: Ability to tell if a ledger is closed or not

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment: attach a patch for this jira, since this ticket is requested for quite a period.
Simple change, lgtm +1

Testing JIRA BOOKKEEPER-562

Patch BOOKKEEPER-562.patch downloaded at Tue Apr 9 07:52:04 UTC 2013

----------------------------

+1 PATCH_APPLIES
+1 CLEAN
-1 RAW_PATCH_ANALYSIS
. +1 the patch does not introduce any @author tags
. +1 the patch does not introduce any tabs
. +1 the patch does not introduce any trailing spaces
. +1 the patch does not introduce any line longer than 120
. -1 the patch does not add/modify any testcase
+1 RAT
. +1 the patch does not seem to introduce new RAT warnings
+1 JAVADOC
. +1 the patch does not seem to introduce new Javadoc warnings
+1 COMPILE
. +1 HEAD compiles
. +1 patch compiles
. +1 the patch does not seem to introduce new javac warnings
+1 FINDBUGS
. +1 the patch does not seem to introduce new Findbugs warnings
+1 TESTS
. Tests run: 833
+1 DISTRO
. +1 distro tarball builds with the patch

----------------------------
-1 Overall result, please check the reported -1(s)

The full output of the test-patch run is available at

. https://builds.apache.org/job/bookkeeper-trunk-precommit-build/321/

Nice that you've had a chance to take a cut at this issue, Sijie. I'm not the one who came up with this requirement, but my understanding of what they need is a bit different.

Your change allows an app to check if the state of the ledger according to the handle is closed. In the way I understand the description here, the app might not have opened or created the ledger to obtain a handle and yet it needs to know if a given ledger is closed, perhaps using something like BookKeeper#isClosed(ledgerId) that queries the metastore. It also mentions listing existing ledgers along with its status (open or closed).

Flavio Junqueira

I think we just need to respond more actively to the community's request. For example this one, and also some other hbase guys requires some kind of location-aware distribution schedules.

go back to this jira, there are two jiras related to their requirements: BOOKKEEPER-562 and BOOKKEEPER-257. for listing ledgers, it would be handled in BOOKKEEPER-257. for this issue, I am not sure what exactly they required. but I think both LedgerHandle#isClosed and BookKeeper#isClosed(ledgerId) are useful. I could add such call to avoid instantiate a LedgerHandle.

Flavio is right on; this is what I was looking for:
BookKeeper#isClosed(ledgerId)
that queries the metastore. It also mentions listing existing ledgers along
with its status (open or closed).

On Tue, Apr 16, 2013 at 12:08 AM, Flavio Junqueira (JIRA)

Sijie Guo

I think we just need to respond more actively to the community's request.

I fully agree, hopefully you didn't get the impression I was complaining about what you have done. I was just trying to point out that the requirement was perhaps a different one. I'm also happy that Whitney has chimed in and clarified.

there are two jiras related to their requirements: BOOKKEEPER-562 and BOOKKEEPER-257.

Agreed, it sounds like there are two different requirements here: determine the state of a single ledger and process all ledgers. For the first one, which belongs in this jira, it sounds like we have converged to something like BookKeeper#isClosed(ledgerId). Having some like LedgerHandle#isClosed is good too.

Hi Sijie, Two questions for you:

  1. Do you agree with having a isClosed(ledgerId) call in either BookKeeper or BookKeeperAdmin instead?
  2. Do you have time to do it or you prefer that I do it?

Now a question for all: do you have a preference of whether we should have isClosed in BookKeeper or BookKeeperAdmin? Since we will have listLedgers (BOOKKEEPER-257) in BookKeeperAdmin, it might be a good idea to have isClosed there too, but I don't really have a strong preference.

Do you agree with having a isClosed(ledgerId) call in either BookKeeper or BookKeeperAdmin instead?

agreed. put it in bookkeeper, since bookkeeperadmin inherits from bookkeeper.

Do you have time to do it or you prefer that I do it?

you could do it if you had time
Here is an attempt to resolve this issue.
Flavio Junqueira patch looks fine. How about to simplify/improve the synchronized block with CountDownLatch, please have a look at the new patch?

Hi Rakesh, Thanks for reviewing it, I'm fine with your change.

Rakesh et al.,Can I have a +1 or other concerns with this patch?

Nit: looks like test code required format
+1 for the latest patch on addressing the above nit. Thanks a lot, Flavio and Rakesh for working on it.

There were some extra spaces in the test case, uploading a new patch with that fixed. Thanks, Uma.

If I get no other comments in the next day or two, I'll commit it, since I have a +1 already.

Patch looks good. We shouldn't use GenericCallback in the public API though, as it's in the proto package. It would be better to define a new "GenericCallback" in AsyncCallback, which can be used by client apis.
Thanks for the feedback, Ivan. Shall we just copy the GenericCallback declaration to AsyncCallback?
I haven't done what I said previously, I created a IsClosedCallback interface. I like this one better.

IsClosedCallback needs a ctx object, and asyncIsClosed also. I don't actual like the ctx objects, but we should keep it consistent.

Also, the code is slight off the coding standard [1]; else should be on the same line as the previous } and there should be spaces around parenthesis, 

if(something){

should be 

if (something) {

.

[1] http://www.oracle.com/technetwork/java/javase/documentation/codeconventions-142311.html#449

I have fixed it according to the comments. One point I was thinking about, it is not necessary to have ledgerId parameter for the complete call, is it? We can always pass it as part of the context object if necessary, but I wanted to make sure that we agree.

Patch looks good. +1. There's no need for ledgerId as part of callback. It can be passed in a number of other ways.

One last thing (you can do it when you push in the patch), is that the javadoc shouldn't describe how the operation occurs, but rather what is does. 

/**
 * Read the ledger metadata for lId and return true if the
 * ledger has been closed asynchronously.

would be better as

/**
 * Check whether ledger, identified by <i>lId</i>, is closed.
 * This is an asynchronous call.

Also, the sync version should say the same (except) for the async part. The description isn't long enough to warrant a redirection.
Committed revision 1479649. Thanks for all reviews.

Integrated in bookkeeper-trunk #195 (See https://builds.apache.org/job/bookkeeper-trunk/195/)
BOOKKEEPER-562: Ability to tell if a ledger is closed or not (fpj) (Revision 1479649)

Result = SUCCESS

Could you upload the final patch to the jira, so it matches what went in.
Here it is.
I checked that the committed patch applies cleanly to the 4.2 branch. Note that the committed patch has modifications to the CHANGES.txt file, which conflict with the current state of the file.
Reopening for 4.2.2.
Committed as r1492321 on branch-4.2
